1: How can the Eye be older than the universe itself?
3: The early universe was unimaginably hot and dense. If anything existed before, it would have been destroyed.
4: Suppose the universe is older than previously assumed.
5: The Ash Twin Project requires a powerful, highly advanced warp core. How should we obtain it?
6: Solution 2: We could craft a new advanced warp core inspired by the Vessel’s warp core.
7: OENO: The greatest challenge here, I think, is we don’t have the design for such a powerful core, or any of the original crafters of the Vessel’s core.
8: CLARY: No, but Poke was apprenticed to Annona, who created the original design, and our Black Hole Forge is adept at crafting simpler cores.
9: POKE: I believe I can be of use here! The Vessel’s warp core was created before my time, but Annona explained many of his designs to me.
10: IDAEA: This is the safest path for our clan.
11: AVENS: Is the safest path the best one? Our goal is worth the risk.
12: CASSAVA: Is it, though? We’ve tried for so long to find something that I (and others) now believe might be impossible to find. If the search for the Eye is a futile one, we should choose the option with the least potential for harm.
13: SPIRE: Abandoning the Vessel’s warp core and its casing means losing valuable knowledge.
14: MITIS: This is true; however, it’s knowledge we have little hope of recovering. It would be best to relearn, I think.
15: POKE: I would very much like to craft such a powerful core! More relevantly, I believe the Black Hole Forge crew and I could recreate the basic design.
16: CASSAVA: I imagine I’ve been hard on Poke, again. This in turn means I’ve made things difficult for her sister (Clary).
17: CASSAVA: If Poke and I are oil and water, Clary is our emulsifier. She certainly makes us a better team than would mixing through shaking (although sometimes I would like to shake Poke!).
18: CASSAVA: Jokes aside, suppose my own fear of never finding the Eye prompted my argument with Poke. That would be immature of me.
19: CASSAVA: I should apologize... At least to Clary, who could then tell Poke.
20: POKE: I feel strange, trying to recreate Annona’s warp core without him. At times, it still feels strange to no longer be his (very young) apprentice, and for the Black Hole Forge to be in my care and not his.
21: POKE: Hypothesis: This will always feel strange. Even though my time with him was short, I miss my old mentor, and deeply.
22: POKE: To have the chance to try is thrilling, but... I don’t want to disappoint everyone. I think I can do this (probably), but what if excitement has clouded my assessment of my own abilities?
23: POKE: Was I wrong in volunteering to build it...? I was born in this star system, and never saw Annona’s warp core with my own three eyes. I only know what he taught me. What if I’ve bitten off a larger portion than I can consume?
24: POKE: Still, all I can give is my best. And as Annona would say, should my best prove insufficient, then we will find another way to achieve what’s needed. I have Clary and Root in the forge, and I have my clan. I am not alone!
26: SOLANUM: No one knows how this universe was made, but one thing we do know is everything used to be very hot and very dense (tightly packed togehter).
27: SOLANUM: As this early universe expanded, it also cooled down. Once it had cooled down enough, particles were able to group together to form things like galaxies, stars, and planets!
28: SOLANUM: Since then, space has continued to expand at a faster and faster rate, which is hard to think about for too long without your brain hurting.
29: SOLANUM: This universe will keep getting colder and larger, until one day, the stars and the life they support will all die.
30: SOLANUM: That’s scary to think about, even though Conoy tells me it won’t happen in our lifetimes. But it’ll happen in someone else’s, someday!
32: LAMI: All the Nomai clans from all over the universe meet in one place to share what they’ve learned in science and art. It’s called the festival!
33: FILIX: Don’t forget, festivals happen every ten years!
34: LAMI: We can’t go because we’re stuck here. But Filix says we used to go, too.
35: LAMI: At some festivals, one clan’s big discovery can mean all the Nomai get to advance, too. Like Annona’s warp core, which made it so everyone can warp long distances and explore more.
36: LAMI: Each clan has a festival envoy to show their most interesting work. (Our envoy was Thatch!)
37: LAMI: A single festival could last a long, long time!
38: PLUME: Use caution! A black hole sleeps below. You must not slip.

48: SPIRE: There also exists a rarer type of cyclone that spins the opposite direction and pushes objects beneath the waters and below the current.

65: BELLS: If you’re here to make your first pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon, you are almost prepared to set out on this deeply significant journey. Before you do, pause, and remember your history.
66: BELLS: We make this journey not only for ourselves, but also to honor the members of our clan who came before us: those who, after the crash that brought them to this star system, became stranded on Brittle Hollow and on Ember Twin, with no communication between these two groups of survivors.
67: BELLS: These Nomai looked upward from two different planets and saw the same wandering moon visiting their skies. It was this moon (the Quantum Moon) that kept their curiosity alive during this long period of hardship.
68: BELLS: After the two divided groups were able to reunite, it became our clan’s united goal to find and visit the Quantum Moon. This took time, and many Nomai who dreamed of seeing the Quantum Moon died before we discovered how to make the journey.
69: BELLS: When you reach the Quantum Moon, recall these Nomai, and carry their curiosity onward with you.
70: PLUME: The trees are moving! The trees in this grove wander about freely (the entire plant, roots and all)! This is not normal, even for this alien planet. And I never see them move! Is that even possible?!
71: PLUME: If anyone else witnesses this disturbing behavior, I implore you, record your observations here. Either these trees are aberrant, or my brain must be!
72: THATCH: Plume is right; the trees do move! I confess I didn’t notice until I read his notes.
73: THATCH: Alarmingly, it isn’t only the trees: There is other matter in this area (such as that unusual shard of rock) moving in this same eerie way.
74: FILIX: That rock is unusual for another reason, too, Thatch: It possesses color and texture I’ve never seen elsewhere on this planet!
75: FILIX: Hypothesis: This rock shard’s presence is significant. We should study it! (Could it be what is causing other nearby objects to also move about this area?)
76: THATCH: Plume, Filix, and I have determined this atypical shard of rock is the reason objects in this grove are behaving in a quantum manner.
77: THATCH: The only other object we’ve observed displaying this quantum behavior is the wandering moon. I imagine the moon’s behavior and this grove’s are related.
78: PLUME: In her note from earlier, Filix mentions this strange type of rock isn’t found elsewhere on Brittle Hollow. What if it isn’t originally from this planet?
79: PLUME: Hypothesis: This “quantum shard” is from the wandering (quantum) moon. Perhaps it is even a small piece of the moon itself.
80: FILIX: Of note: A unique signal is coming from this shard! Curiously, our friend the wandering moon sounds the same.
81: FILIX: I’ve also heard the same signal this shard produces calling out from Giant’s Deep,Timber Hearth, and the Hourglass Twins. Suppose there are other shards like this one!
82: BELLS: Welcome, Solanum! Your arrival here means you’ve completed your preparations on Giant’s Deep and are ready to depart for the Quantum Moon.
83: BELLS: On your pilgrimage, the Quantum Moon will carry you, just as it carried me and many in our clan before me, to the moon’s sixth and most secret location.
84: BELLS: You’ll be aided in your pilgrimage by the shrine our clan built on the Quantum Moon. But remember this final rule: To explore the sixth location, the shrine must be on the moon’s north pole.
85: BELLS: Be curious on your journey!
86: BELLS: Be welcomed in this place! Above you stands the Tower of Quantum Knowledge.
87: BELLS: If you are making your first pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon, ascend these stairs, and obtain the last of the knowledge you need for your journey.
88: BELLS: Beneath your feet lies the Tower of Quantum Knowledge.
89: BELLS: If you are preparing to make your first pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon, descend the steps to the entrance below. The knowledge held within will help you on your journey.

103: MELORAE: The heat from this star system’s sun is more bearable below the surface.
104: MELORAE: When our escape pod punctured this planet’s surface, it broke into what scans show is a cave system with much cooler air. I would recommend we seek a site down there to build a long-term shelter, Annona, but these passages are a maze!
105: ANNONA: Even with this danger, they are still our best chance for survival. We’ll form teams and descend into the caves to look for a shelter site. We can mark our findings on the walls to avoid becoming irreversibly lost.
107: RHUS: And be aware of the sand as you search. It appears to be rising gradually.
108: COLEUS: The path to the shelter site is somewhat convoluted, so follow the instructions ahead closely!
109: COLEUS: To reach the shelter site, walk forward until you meet the sandfall at the pit, then turn left. Continue to the room filled with rock column formations and climb upward through the opening above them.
110: COLEUS: The sand here is rising, so you must be cautious but swift.
111: COLEUS: Be cautious crossing the chasm ahead. The bridge Melorae and I crafted will do its job, but it isn’t strong.

113: COLEUS: You’re doing well! There’s only a little farther left to go now until you reach the shelter site. You can rest there. Hurry, before the sand comes!
114: MELORAE: Do not follow this tunnel to its end! (Coleus and I will examine the horror that lies at its terminus later, provided we live through this.)
115: ANNONA: Of note: This passage leads to breathable air. Refill your supply tank there (we cannot tell how far or deep these tunnels may wind), but do not linger, as the area is exposed to the heat of this alien sun.
116: ANNONA: Refill your air supply tank and return quickly.
117: RHUS: Keep moving, friends: There is nothing of interest at the end of this passage but rocks.
118: RHUS: And while these rocks are interesting, they can wait until a less urgent time.

138: PYE: I’m receiving much stronger energy readings now that we’re beneath the crust. Whatever it is must lie somewhere below, closer to the comet’s center. And I’m starting to think it’s more dangerous than we realized.
139: PYE: Clary, can you hear us?
140: CLARY: Yes, but your voices are faint. I fear we will lose communication entirely if you continue any deeper.
141: POKE: Keep the shuttle warm for us, Clary. We’ll return the moment we identify the source of the energy readings!
142: CLARY: I understand, but... Be cautious, both of you.
143: POKE: The spherical stone casing here seems to be the source of the energy readings... No, rather, the source is what’s within the stone. I’m detecting some form of exotic matter.
144: PYE: The stone is muting our energy readings; they should be ten times what we’re seeing, at least.
145: POKE: Pye, I don’t think we want this matter interacting with us. As far as I can tell, direct contact with it would almost certainly be fatal.
146: PYE: I’ve never encountered anything like this casing, but it’s all that’s protecting us from what’s inside. Worse still, this matter is disturbingly volatile.
147: POKE: ...Pye. Whatever the matter inside this stone casing is, it’s more than just profoundly unstable; it’s under tonnes of pressure. Look at this density scan. I’ve never seen anything this tightly compacted before! What is this?
148: PYE: This is orders of magnitude worse than I’d imagined. If this stone were to rupture, the lethal matter within would rapidly expand, completely blanketing this star system almost instantaneously. And the pressure is still building as the comet approaches this star system...
149: PYE: Return to the shuttle, right now! The rest of our friends need to know they’re in terrible danger. Leave your equipment and run!
150: POKE: What are you doing, Pye?!
151: PYE: The more we know about this alien matter, the better our chances of survival. I will learn what I can here. Go, warn the others; maybe they can construct shelter somehow. ...Now, Poke!
152: CLARY: I fear our situation may be dire:
153: CLARY: Pye, Poke, and I landed here on this comet not long after its arrival in this star system. Our shuttle’s equipment heard strange energy readings coming from somewhere beneath the surface.
154: CLARY: Pye and Poke were able to locate a fissure in the ice on the comet’s sunward side, and they descended inside to investigate the source of the readings.
155: CLARY: But... Pye and my sister have been gone for a long time now. They haven’t contacted me since descending below the surface, either.
156: CLARY: Should I leave the shuttle to look for them? I want to follow protocol, but I don’t know what I’ll do if they aren’t well...
157: CLARY: Poke... Pye... Come back to me safely, my friends.
158: CLARY: This is troublesome: It seems the comet wishes to submerge our shuttle in ice. If we stay on the surface too long, the shuttle may freeze entirely.
159: POKE: Even if it did, couldn’t someone call it back home to the gravity cannon on Ember Twin?
160: PYE: Yes, but the exploration of the comet would be more difficult if we were without the shuttle until someone recalled it. Perhaps we shouldn’t have landed on the dark side of the comet...
161: CLARY: Suppose one of us remained in the shuttle to keep it warm and continue monitoring the surface.
162: PYE: This would be wise, I think, Clary. If you don’t mind waiting here with it, Poke and I can continue to investigate the surface.

310: CLARY: Regarding the warp towers on Ash Twin: Does each tower have to be perfectly aligned with the center of the astral body to which it’s tuned?
311: CLARY: I enjoy precision as much as the next Nomai, but if, for example, a tower’s base were to shift even slightly, that tower might no longer align with its astral body.
312: POKE: We don’t need the alignment angle to be exact; it only needs to be within five degrees of the astral body’s center.
313: POKE: Of note: This gives us a slightly longer warp window. I imagine this window will last roughly several seconds.
314: POKE: As such, any Nomai stepping onto the warp platform during the active window will be immediately warped. We will need to be careful around the platform for the duration of the time it’s active to avoid accidental transportation.

358: COLEUS: How else would he improve?
359: Ash Twin warp network status: All towers online.
362: POKE: Welcome to the White Hole Station! If you fell through the black hole by accident (don't worry, you aren’t the first), this warp tower can return you to Brittle Hollow.
363: POKE: Every warp tower is tuned to a specific astral body. A tower's warp can only be used during the brief window when the tower is aligned with its corresponding astral body (in this case, Brittle Hollow).
364: You must be standing on the warp platform on the floor during this alignment to be warped.
365: POKE: If you look up while the station is rotating, you can see the alignment happens when the astral body is directly overhead.
367: Nice, it’s you. Good to see you made it here in one piece. The first solo launch is a doozy, isn’t it?
368: So hey, don’t freak out or anything, but lately I keep, like, dying repeatedly. I dunno, it’s pretty weird.
369: What about you? Have you died lately, or is it just me?
370: No, it’s me, too. We’re in a time loop.
371: Time has been behaving unusually lately. Yeah, a time loop makes sense. Cool.
373: What did you think it was?
375: Personally, I like new experiences, and I’ve never been in a time loop before. I mean, I don’t think I’ve been in a time loop before this one.
376: I figured it’d be some kind of fidgety time business, but I wasn’t really thinking about what’s happening to the shape of time, you know? But a loop makes sense here. Let’s go with “loop” for now.
377: It looks like you and I are the only ones who can tell that time’s gone all weird. I tried radioing Hornfels and asking if they’d died, too, but they thought I was being metaphorical.
378: Even if I tell Hornfels about the time loop, they never remember by the next one. They don’t realize anything’s different.
379: And here’s another weird one for you - every time I die, all of my memories from that loop replay back to me. I’m pretty sure that’s related to this big stone Nomai statue I found on one of the other islands.
380: I was looking at it, and the statue opened its eyes and started glowing. It replayed my memories like it’d seen them through my own eyes, just like what happens each time I die.
381: That happened to me with the statue at the museum.
382: You too, huh? Then the Nomai statues must have something to do with why we’re the only ones aware of the time loop. So... no glowing statue, no time loop awareness?
383: I think that’s going to be my leading theory, but if you find out anything new about the statues or the time loop, let me know, okay? I’ll be here.
384: Anyway, that’s what’s new with me. But hey, this is your first solo voyage! ...Kind of! Let’s talk about you, you know?
385: Have you ever watched a cyclone for so long, it started to hypnotize you? I’m telling you, they’ll put you in a trance if you stare at ’em long enough.
388: What are you doing out here?
389: Where should I explore on Giant’s Deep?
395: Well, what are any of us doing here, really?
396: ...Nah, I’m just kidding. I’m out here exploring our solar system, same as you.
397: But I tell you what, outer space really gives you room to think. It’s quiet and peaceful out here.
398: I mean, it’s usually quiet and peaceful. Sometimes a cyclone comes by and lifts my little island paradise clean out of the water. Then: less peaceful.
399: Here’s something you might like — at the start of every time loop, I keep seeing a bright flash in the sky. Something must be happening up there in orbit around the planet.
400: What else, what else... Have you been to Statue Island? That’s what I’ve been calling it, seeing as it’s the island where I found the glowing Nomai statue. ...Get it?

405: There’s a strong current a ways beneath the surface that prevents anything from sinking below it. Seriously, I tried everything I could think of to get past that current, and neither idea worked.
406: As for land masses, I’ve counted four islands, including this one. There’s also the one with that Nomai statue I saw on the beach.
407: You’ve seen the cyclones? Yeah, they’re hard to miss. They’ll toss up everything in their path, islands included. Little tip — if you get picked up, try to land in water. Less likely to kill you.
409: It’s definitely on this planet somewhere. I mean, unless a cyclone came by and tossed it into space, I guess. Heh, that would be pretty nuts.
411: An excellent question. I haven’t seen it around lately.
413: Oh, cool. So it’s floating in the ocean, huh?
414: Did it look like it was having a good time?

416: Cool, cool. Take it easy out there.

427: Right, right, the cavern inside Statue Island is where the memory-recording statues were made, I remember.

440: Meaning we’re receiving memories of things that will never happen to us. Cool, huh?

576: Hear that, pal? You’re in great shape. Keep up the good work out here!
579: The old radio tower, while an important landmark, is unfortunately closed thanks to the unsanctioned flight testing of an extremely powerful model rocket.
580: While we hope to repair the radio tower in the future, all construction efforts are currently focused on the planned museum expansion at the Observatory.
581:
Sincerest apologies, except to Slate and Mica, 
Hornfels (museum curator)
582: The radio tower here on Timber Hearth was built to receive transmissions from our deep space satellite, and to this day still houses the first-ever photos taken of the entire solar system.
583: These photos were made possible by the deep space satellite’s unusual vertical orbit that carries it high above (and below) the plane of the solar system.
584: Thanks to a recent upgrade, the deep space satellite is now responsible for generating the real-time solar system map used by our newest astronauts.
585: Our new expansion was made possible by the generous contributions of esteemed museum visitors like you. Thank you very much for your support!
586: FUTURE SITE OF OUR NEXT EXHIBIT!
587: If you’ve enjoyed your time with Outer Wilds, please consider supporting our planned museum expansion.
588: Our quest to explore the furthest reaches of our solar system wouldn’t be possible without generous visitors like you! We thank you profusely for your support, and we hope to see you again soon.
590: There’s our pilot! Back from your pre-launch campout under the stars, I see.
591: So it’s Launch Day, eh? Seems like only yesterday you joined the space program, and suddenly here you are, leaving on your first solo voyage.
592: What do you say - ready to get this beauty off the ground? It’s all fueled up and ready to go!
595: You’re sure you fixed the retro rockets?
596: Hey, you ready to get this thing off the ground? Ship’s all fueled and ready to go.
600: You’re sure you fixed the retro rockets?
601: Whoa, bad dream or something? You still look half asleep, but that’s a negative on being deceased.
602: I know it’s tradition to sleep out under the stars the night before a launch, but if you ask me it makes you all a bit jumpy.
603: Glad you’re excited, but remember, if you wreck the ship I’m not building you a new one. I’m not made of lightweight reentry grade aluminum alloys, you know.
604: Are you kidding? Of course I’m ready - it’s finally time to test the new landing hydraulics with a pilot instead of the autoflight system!
605: ...Speaking of pilots, make sure you don’t crash the ship the first time you put it down, you hear?
606: That was only a problem one time. And then maybe a few times after that, but hey, no reason to dwell on the past, right?
607: Anyway, you’ll need to get the launch codes from Hornfels at the observatory before you can lift off. Just bring those here once you’ve said your goodbyes or whatever.
608: Not having second thoughts, are you?
609: Where are the launch codes again?
611: How safe would you say this thing is?
612: What’s my mission once I’m in space?
613: What else should I do before liftoff?
614: Hey, you’re the pilot - you tell me. Aren’t you pilot-types all eager to get up there and explore for yourselves?
615: Doesn’t matter if you go to the moon or Brittle Hollow or just the other side of Timber Hearth. It’s all the same to me. Get out there and have fun!
616: Just don’t hurt the ship, that’s all I ask.
617: If you have any goodbyes to say, better say ’em now. I think your friend Hal is in the observatory waiting to see you off.
618: Oh, and Gossan says they have the zero-g chamber set up if you want a refresher on making ship repairs in space. Not saying you have to, but uh, it’d help get Gossan off my back if you did.
619: Hornfels has the launch codes. Should be up at the observatory, like usual. I’m starting to think they live there.
620: Great! Hey, you might get a kick out of this - I’ve repurposed the spare oxygen tank to be used as an extra combustion chamber!
623:
Well, it’s all very conceptual, but basically, it’s like taking a regular second-stage booster and strapping a bigger rocket onto it.
Isn’t that great?
625:
Oh, it’s a perfect ten. Unless you’re factoring in pilot error, in which case it’s about a four. 
No offense.
626: Oh, hold up, you’re going to want to get the launch codes from the observatory first.

628: How did I get back here? Didn’t I already lift off?
629: Wait, did I just die, or...?
630: Huh. Must be inhaling more fumes than I realized. That stuff is potent.
631: Well, if you’ve got the codes, I’m not gonna stop you. Good luck, and take care of that ship!
632: Trust me -- with the modifications I’ve made to those rockets? There’s no way I would have missed that.

634: Uh, no...? You have a bad dream or something?

636:

We’re working on fixing the autopilot’s avoidance system for this one!

639: Hey, what can I do you for?

650: Make sure the sun isn’t between you and your destination when you engage autopilot, and you’ll be fine.

803:
GABBRO’S 3 FOOLPROOF STEPS FOR DOZING OFF 
1. Light a nice, cozy campfire and get comfortable. 
2. Gaze deeply into the serene warmth. 
3. Let time begin to slip away as you allow the flames to lull you into a peaceful slumber.
804: (If Gabbro knew I’d taken notes, they’d probably think I’d finally cracked, but I refuse to accept sass from an astronaut who deliberately burns their marshmallows.)
805: Charting stars again out by the radio tower — they’re so bright out here! I only wish I were able to record them faster. Admittedly, I could use more patience. I get so engrossed in my work that sunrise becomes an unwelcome deadline, and daylight a grating slog.

809: Every single astral body in our magnificent solar system, looking stunning from every angle in each of these three images. And in color, no less! Now this is art. I could stare at these photos forever. Doesn’t Timber Hearth look tiny from —

824: What they could not unlearn was hidden away in darkness — obfuscated, then lost. They did not want to see their story end.
825: My kind weren’t always like this. We weren’t always so afraid. I did what I could to set things right, yet I am still of my kind, and you know now what they did. I cannot promise our fear won’t stain your mind.

838: The radio tower on Timber Hearth was built to receive transmissions from our deep space satellite, and housed some of the last-ever photos taken of the entire solar system.
839: Hornfels noticed a curious anomaly in one of the photos, but it ultimately went unexplained.
840: The radio tower on Timber Hearth was built to receive transmissions from our deep space satellite, and housed some of the last-ever photos taken of the entire solar system.
841: One of these photos revealed the existence of an invisible ring world inhabited by a species whose presence in our solar system predated even the Nomai.
842: This species traveled from a nearby star system in search of the Eye of the universe, but, horrified by what they discovered, decided to block the Eye’s signal so that no one else would ever find it.
843: One individual, however, rebelled against the decision, and was able to briefly release the Eye’s signal back into space before being caught and imprisoned in solitude for this betrayal.

909: ANNONA: The Quantum Moon locator is functioning. We have markers for each of the places the moon goes.
910: MELORAE: Annona, Bur, I just observed the Quantum Moon in orbit around Dark Bramble.

914: MELORAE: It’s also possible there exists a sixth place in this star system to which the phantom moon travels.

916: Annona: Your strange, wandering rock friend is here, though Coleus isn’t.

921: Should we build the Sun Station to power the Ash Twin Project?
922: IDAEA: I almost can’t comprehend this is being suggested seriously. The purpose of the Sun Station goes against every standard we hold ourselves to and everything we believe in as a species!
923: PYE: Unsurprisingly, Idaea, I disagree. We’re pushing a possible new technology further than ever before. That, in my experience, is the defining characteristic of our species.
924: YARROW: Are there other ways to generate this level of power?
925: PYE: Theoretically, yes. Practically, no. I can’t imagine discovering them in our lifetimes...
926: RAMIE: I understand this proposal is unsettling, but the Sun Station must be built if we hope to complete the Ash Twin Project.
927: COLEUS: If we fail (and the probability of this is not insignificant), we will without question destroy ourselves, all life here, and the rest of this star system. I wish to protect these species.
928: IDAEA: The potential annihilation of an entire star system is too severe a cost. We shouldn’t build the Sun Station, no matter how badly we want the knowledge that comes with it.
929: POKE: Fear of failure is a poor reason not to try. I believe, if we’re cautious, the Sun Station will work. I believe in Pye.
930: PYE: Poke, I’m deeply honored. Idaea, I comprehend your position; however, if we aren’t all but certain the Sun Station will not cause destruction once we’ve built it, then I won’t support the station’s use.
931: RAMIE: Note: This door will need to remain closed for some time! Pye and I are running an experiment based on the extraordinary findings from the White Hole Station.
932: PYE: Ramie and I will be running this experiment until one of us (specifically, me) can prove the other wrong, so although it’s inconvenient, the lab currently can only be accessed by the path from the Sunless City.
933: RAMIE: Inviting sand inside would disrupt our setup and could have enormous consequences. (We realize this is an intriguing prospect, but the door must remain closed nonetheless!)
934: RAMIE: An update: The High Energy Lab is now being used to design the Ash Twin Project! If you’re here to help (or even just to observe), be sure to use the Sunless City path to the lab.
935: RAMIE: The Southern Observatory is asking if creating a 22 minute interval is possible (that is, to have something arrive 22 minutes before it is actually sent through the warp).
936: RAMIE: We’ve learned the negative interval of time between departure and arrival can be increased by adding more energy to the warp core. Problematically, the energy required to extend the interval increases at an exponential rate.
937: PYE: Hypothesis: Creating a 22-minute-long interval is possible, but we are currently unable to generate the necessary energy.
938: PYE: Ramie and I believe it would be necessary to invent a new method of producing energy, a thrilling but enormous undertaking. We would also require advanced warp technology able to handle such energy.
939: PYE: We would also likely need an enormous space to fit these proposed new energy and warp technologies together. The only location large enough would be Ash Twin.
940: RAMIE: The energy is currently unavailable, you say? You’re a gas, Pye!
941: PYE: My pun was unintended, Ramie, so I believe it’s you who’s aeriform!
942: PYE: Records show Nomai arriving at the warp receiver on Brittle Hollow very slightly before departing from the White Hole Station. Ramie and I are devising an experiment to test if this is a real phenomenon or simple machine error.
943: RAMIE: In theory, what we want to try to reproduce is a negative amount of time elapsing between something entering the black hole and exiting the white hole at its destination.
944: PYE: Initial things first: Our experiment setup will first pair a small black hole core with a small white hole core to mimic the setup on the White Hole Station.
945: RAMIE: Hypothesis: It is possible for an object to exit a white hole before entering the corresponding black hole.
946: RAMIE: An update: Our experiment here reproduced the anomaly in arrival and departure times, but Pye is unconvinced it’s more than an equipment error. I hope to strengthen the effect to render it visible to the unaided eyes.
947: PYE: To that end, we’ve decided to try adding more energy. I imagine the Sunless City’s energy supply should prove sufficient.
948: PYE: Of note, Ramie: Yarrow requests that we let him know before we reroute energy to the experiment.
949: RAMIE: I’d hate to leave him in the dark!
950: PYE: All available energy has been rerouted from the city to our experiment. Ramie and I are about to run a new test.
951: RAMIE: Hypothesis confirmed! Hypothesis confirmed! I saw it! Pye saw it! Hypothesis confirmed!
952: PYE: This is beyond extraordinary! This changes everything! What a beautiful day for the intersection of abstract theory and practical application!
953: SECCA: Our escape pod crashed as we tried to flee this place, destroying our movement and communication capabilities in the process.
954: SECCA: We’ve held out as long as we could here, but this pod’s supply of breathable air is nearly depleted, and the anglerfish attack more and more frequently.
955: SECCA: Our best chance at survival is to return to the Vessel to either repair the damage or, more probably, await rescue.
956: ESCALL: Secca, is the message finished? The Vessel’s beacon is already growing fainter; it will be gone in a matter of hours. We need to leave here, quickly.
957: CANNA: To any Nomai clans whose Vessels can hear this message:
958: CANNA: It’s clear the universe is dying. There are fewer and fewer resources and safe places within space now, so my clan and I believe the best option is for all of our clans to stay together.
959: CANNA: If you can reach the Gloaming Galaxy, we’ve found that Blackrock’s suns are fairly stable, and life in this star system is (comparatively) thriving. We live in relative safety.
960: CANNA: If you prefer to continue exploring alone, know you will be on your own.
961: BROMI: Canna, we’re making our way to you.
962: CANNA: It’s good to hear from you, Bromi! We’ll watch for your Vessel.
963: CANNA: Has anyone heard from Neem? His clan was on its way to our Vessel, but they never arrived, and he hasn’t sent any messages. I’m beginning to worry.
964: BROMI: That is unsettling. It reminds me of that old myth my grandfather used to tell, the Disappearance of Escall.
965: CLEM: I remember hearing that story as a child! One day, Escall’s Vessel simply stopped responding. The other clans searched and searched, but found no trace. It was as if their missing friends had warped out of existence.
966: HYSSOP: That’s no myth, friends; Escall’s clan existed, and their story was real.
967: BROMI: What a curious event to have passed into myth! Our ancestors’ ancestors were told that story when they were young. Are you sure it’s true, Hyssop?
968: HYSSOP: It was a very long time ago, but yes. My clan’s ancestors searched for Escall’s clan for a long time, but in the end, none of them were ever seen again. (It’s the only time in our history a Vessel has ever disappeared this way.)
969: NEEM: Hyssop, I hope you aren’t comparing Escall’s story to my clan’s Vessel!
970: CLEM: Neem, my friend! We feared you were gone!
971: NEEM: Not yet, we aren’t, but nearly. We found trouble during our warp: The triple suns of the Bright Spark star system exploded, and it was only a lucky coincidence we weren’t caught in the blast. We’ll meet you soon, Canna!
972: CANNA: I’m relieved your clan is safe, Neem! It’s good to hear your words. Any Vessels nearby, remember to be extremely cautious of potentially unstable stars (which is most of them, now).
973: FILIX: This is Escall’s Vessel; something went badly wrong during our warp, and our Vessel is mortally wounded. We need help as quickly as possible!
974: FILIX: Our Vessel appears to have... has it fused with the local environment, somehow? There are vines that are now part of the Vessel! It’s been torn apart from inside itself!
975: FILIX: We... we are abandoning our Vessel. Any Nomai clans or spaceflight-capable species receiving this message, I implore you, we need your help!
976: FILIX: Is this broken? Can anyone hear me? Our Vessel is dying! We need immediate assistance!
977: FILIX: I’m recording now — I’ve never encountered anything like this! The signal the Vessel is receiving appears to be older than the universe itself!
978: ESCALL: This is our first contact with anything of this nature. Everyone, prepare to warp immediately!
979: FILIX: Escall, wait, I need more time to send an outgoing message! Shouldn’t we tell another clan where we’re going?
980: ESCALL: We can send the message upon our arrival. This extraordinary signal appeared suddenly; it may disappear just as quickly, and we can’t lose a discovery this incredible! Focus on preparing for the warp, instead.
982: ESCALL: Annona, is the Vessel ready to warp to the signal’s approximate coordinates?
983: ANNONA: The warp core is powered, but this will be a significant jump. Afterward, we’ll need time to recharge the core.
984: ESCALL: That shouldn’t create a problem, provided we arrive at or near the signal’s source. Everyone, we’re ready to warp!
985: CASSAVA: This is it: We’ve finished building the final Orbital Probe Cannon module and are ready to send it into orbit around Giant’s Deep for assembly!
986: CASSAVA: To all my friends here at the Construction Yard, my gratitude for your tireless work. I had given up hope, but I truly believe this cannon may actually succeed where many other attempts have not.
987: DAZ: Are you going gelatinous on us, love? I’m delighted by your words, but they’re atypical for you!
988: CASSAVA: If I’m ever half as gooey as Mallow and Avens behave together, Daz, you may launch me from the Orbital Probe Cannon.
989: CASSAVA: Our next step will be to send Privet up to the Orbital Probe Cannon to install the probe tracking system.
990: DAZ: If I know my brother, Avens (and his spouse) will want to launch the probe with as much power as possible. I’m worried the cannon would break under the strain.
991: DAZ: I propose we give Avens and Mallow a slightly lower maximum power setting than the absolute maximum possible to create room for their enthusiasm.
992: Be welcomed in this place. This tower shares with all who ask the knowledge needed to make his or her first quantum journey.
993: Enter this place without friends, however; these are lessons to learn for yourself.
995: Observing a quantum object; observing an image of a quantum object. These are the same.
996: This is the last one (but we made it harder).
997: LAMI: They’re going to test the memory statues tonight! Phlox says it could be dangerous, so we can’t come.
998: LAMI: But, what if we didn’t use the door and snuck in the other way? Does anyone want to?
999: TAGET: Phlox specifically told us not to do that.
1000: LAEVI: I really want to see the test, too, Lami, but that’s a huge risk to take. We probably shouldn’t. Maybe Phlox’ll let us see a later test.
1002: SOLANUM: I am here! After watching it wander the skies for so long, I am about to stand (for the first time) on the Quantum Moon.
1003: SOLANUM: As expected, my shuttle has landed at the moon’s south pole. I will make the remainder of my journey on foot.
1004: SOLANUM: We don’t know why the Quantum Moon always welcomes its visitors at the south pole, just that this is true.
1005: SOLANUM: As a child, I considered such unknowns sinister. Now, though, I understand they bear no ill will. The universe is, and we are.
1008: PYE: Mission: Science compels us to explode the sun!
1009: IDAEA: Here’s a better one. Mission: Determine if it’s possible to prompt the sun to explode.
1010: IDAEA: Can’t we change this? I don’t enjoy working in view of such a morbid mission statement.
1011: PYE: But it’s accurate. We’re going to create a supernova for the purpose of scientific progress. That’s our mission.
1012: IDAEA: Our mission is to decide if such an irresponsible feat is even possible.
1013: PYE: You lack a sense of humor.
1014: IDAEA: At least I don’t lack a sense of ethics!
1015: PYE: Kindly refrain from going supernova on me before the sun does, Idaea.
1016: THATCH: Where should this new, more sophisticated locator be built? It may need to be larger than this Eye signal locator is.
1017: PLUME: The southern glacier on Brittle Hollow has ample available space. I could construct a new building to house this proposed locator.
1018: FILIX: Yes, let’s build there! I imagine our young friend Conoy would enjoy that immensely. He’s always held a great interest in the Eye, especially for a child born so long after the crash.
1019: PLUME: I will begin construction on Brittle Hollow’s south pole immediately, then!
1020: COLEUS: Annona and those of us originally stranded on Ember Twin built a Quantum Moon locator there, but the heat of the sun made its construction challenging. I wouldn’t recommend building on that planet.
1021: COLEUS: After closer observation, mining site 2a wouldn’t be safe for the native life dwelling in some of this cave’s pools, so (unfortunately) we’ll have to mine one of the other sites.
1022: COLEUS: On the opposite hand, new life! This species is semi-aquatic, and very hardy. The ecosystem here is quite robust, so I believe they’ll thrive in the long run. Be cautious near the pools if you visit 2a to meet them.
1023: CYCAD: There are a few other cave sites that look promising. What about site 2b (it shares similar formations and strata)?
1024: OENO: This sounds promising! Will you and your mentor investigate? If mining site 2b proves safe for this native species, we’ll move our work there.
1025: CYCAD: Site 2b is safe! Coleus says we’ll continue to monitor our activity and its effect on life here.
1026: CYCAD: I was watching them once during a rest, and the hours escaped from me. They’re fascinating (I wonder what their fourth eye does)!
1027: COLEUS: They remind me of a subterranean species that my mentor, Melorae, once told me about (from when our clan used to travel across this universe). I imagine she would have enjoyed these lifeforms greatly.
1028: CASSAVA: We’re nearly ready! Filix and I have finished construction, and she says calibrating the device won’t take long.
1029: FILIX: Fortunately, the Attlerock’s lack of atmosphere will make calibration simple. After all this time, I’m thrilled to finally resume our search!
1030: Caution: You are about to access the core while the Ash Twin Project is active.
1031: WARNING: Removing the core will disable the Ash Twin Project.
1033: YARROW: Today we finished the excavation of Ash Twin. Here, in this space we carved, we will craft our most ambitious project yet: the Ash Twin Project, powerful enough to send information back in time.
1034: COLEUS: We’ve also finished relocating all subterranean plants we met while digging.
1035: RAMIE: We’ll need to keep our eyes on how significantly we’ve altered the environment here.
1036: PYE: How far we’ve come since our experiments at the High Energy Lab! I still can hardly believe Ramie’s hypothesis was true.
1037: YARROW: Poke just sent the warp core for the final tower to us from the Black Hole Forge. Now Ash Twin can be connected with Giant’s Deep, where Cassava is working with Avens to craft the Orbital Probe Cannon, and where Phlox is sculpting the memory statues.
1038: CASSAVA: Hypothesis: It was not by accident the core of our warp tower was the last to be forged.
1039: POKE: Hypothesis: The cores could have been forged faster if Cassava had interrupted my work less frequently to ask for updates.
1040: YARROW: The important point is we are all connected through Ash Twin now, and also that I’m no longer needed for mediating your disagreements.
1041: YARROW: Our friends on Giant’s Deep tested the Orbital Probe Cannon today. Mallow tells me the cannon is doing well, and that Avens advocates for more launch power. If anyone can coax the maximum power from a device, Avens can.
1042: YARROW: But then, if anyone can goad a device into exploding, that, too, is likely Avens. Perhaps I should check in with the Orbital Probe Cannon crew in the interest of safety.
1043: YARROW: Would it help to remind Avens that Mallow (his love) will be one of the Nomai aboard the cannon, or is Mallow part of the problem?
1044: YARROW: Pye and Idaea have worked hard on the Sun Station, and it at last is complete. If everything goes as planned, this structure will prompt the sun’s explosion, which will in turn supply the power the Ash Twin Project requires.
1045: RAMIE: I’m impressed by their mental fortitude. This was the project’s most difficult task, in more ways than one.
1046: YARROW: We’re nearly ready to activate the Ash Twin Project! Here is what will happen: First, the Sun Station will receive the order to fire at the sun, prompting it to explode.
1047: YARROW: Using the energy from the resulting supernova, the Ash Twin Project will send the order for the Orbital Probe Cannon to fire back in time by 22 minutes.
1048: YARROW: Exactly 22 minutes after these orders are received, the Sun Station will again trigger the supernova to send the probe data from this cannon launch back in time.
1049: YARROW: In total, each cycle created by the Ash Twin Project will last precisely 22 minutes. We can end this cycle at will.
1050: YARROW: These words are difficult to write: The Sun Station did not work.
1051: YARROW: However, this is the closest we have ever been. The Ash Twin Project is theoretically sound; we were only unable to power it. Perhaps there is another way.
1052: PYE: Suppose we redesign the Sun Station. To generate power of that magnitude, a supernova is still our only viable option.
1053: IDAEA: This is easier expressed than accomplished.
1054: PYE: You can wait for the sun to explode on its natural timeline if you prefer, Idaea, but you’ll need to find some way to halt our aging process.
1055: RAMIE: I believe we can still find a way to create a supernova, my friend. Don’t lose hope!
1056: YARROW: We are halting our research into creating a supernova for this moment; a comet has newly arrived in this solar system, and we’re anxious to explore it.
1057: YARROW: It’s been a very long time since we last explored somewhere new, so we’re excited to welcome this comet. Imagine what knowledge might be gained there!
1058: PYE: Friends visiting from the Hanging City, we are planning the Ash Twin Project at the High Energy Lab on Ember Twin’s equator.
1059: CONOY: I became lost on Ember Twin (my gratitude that Ramie found me!), but the High Energy Lab is the building with the large solar panels. I’m suprised I didn’t see it!
1060: RAMIE: I imagine our otherwise immensely clever Conoy would lose his own head if it weren’t anatomically impossible!
1061: The shuttle is currently resting at the Quantum Moon.
1062: What is the Eye of the universe?
1063: The Eye is the source of the signal that brought us here.
1064: Suppose the Eye is a more advanced being.
1065: The Eye is older than this universe, so imagine how much it could teach us.
1066: Perhaps it is a cosmic library!
1068: Suppose the Eye wishes to communicate.
1069: The signal is a call. Were we the intended audience?
1070: The signal is the Eye’s voice. It speaks a language we don’t yet know.
1071: Or maybe the signal is the Eye’s attempt at expressing itself.
1072: Of note: From the signal, we were able to determine the Eye’s approximate age (or perhaps its lack of age?).
1073: Be welcomed in this place. This shrine is a space to reflect on what brought us to this star system: the signal from the Eye.
1074: We observed the Eye’s signal in our travels, and followed it here to find its source.
1075: What we know is this: The source of the signal (which we have chosen to call the Eye of the universe) is older than this universe itself. The rest, we have yet to learn.
1076: Enter, and open your mind to its possibilities.
1077: Solution 1: We could retrieve the warp core from the Vessel.
1078: RAMIE: The Vessel’s warp core is broken, at best (recall those present when the Vessel crashed said it sustained lethal injuries). There is no guaranteed reward for this risk.
1079: CONOY: Perhaps we could still repair it. My grandmother told me there was little time to assess the nature or extent of the damage.
1080: CASSAVA: Even if it no longer functions, the old core could be a valuable blueprint, provided we’re able to transport it back here.
1081: PHLOX: This would require a return to Dark Bramble. Plume (my father) said many good Nomai perished there.
1082: CYCAD: My mentor (Coleus) and his old mentor once discovered and studied an anglerfish fossil on Ember Twin. Using that knowledge, we could avoid the anglerfish entirely!
1083: COLEUS: What Melorae and I learned from that fossil would theoretically help us evade the anglerfish, but our hypothesis was never tested on a live specimen.
1084: RAMIE: I remember that anglerfish fossil! We used to play in Fossil Fish Cave when we were children.
1085: SOLANUM: I no longer believe, as I did as a child on Ember Twin, that the Eye of the universe (the source of the signal) wishes to harm us. But it may not want to be found, either.
1086: SOLANUM: The terrible circumstances of our arrival here were almost certainly exactly that: circumstance.
1087: SOLANUM: I suspect imagining we are special to the Eye in some way is wishful thinking. The Eye might have called out to any sentient species.
1088: SOLANUM: Or it might not have been calling out at all, and that my ancestors heard the Eye’s signal holds no great, deep meaning.
1089: SOLANUM: This wouldn’t be so bad, I think.
1090: SOLANUM: In fact, the Eye may not have wishes at all. We have no evidence supporting this.
1091: ILEX: Why We Should Build A New Vessel
1092: ILEX: Each Nomai clan explores the universe in its own Vessel. The Vessel is the heart of every clan.
1093: ILEX: It’s unusual for Nomai to remain in one place for so long. Nomai are wanderers and have no permanent home.
1094: ILEX: If we built a new Vessel, we could return to our adventurous way of life. Imagine all the new places we could go! Our clan wouldn’t be stuck here in this star system.
1095: ILEX: We could even meet with other Nomai, and learn from them, like Coleus says we used to do.
1096: ILEX: It probably wouldn’t be hard to get parts if we stopped building other new things, and if we broke down other structures (like the towers on Ash Twin) for parts.
1097: ILEX: We might have to build a smaller Vessel for now, even though Vessels are normally large. But we could make it bigger later once we reach planets with more resources.
1098: ILEX: It would also help if we stopped building so many things to search for the Eye of the universe. I asked Yarrow, and he says we use lots of resources on the Ash Twin Project.
1099: ILEX: We could even have a warp core for jumping long distances like Vessels have. Poke tells me she plans to make a very advanced warp core for a different project. I’m sure she could connect it to the Vessel for travel (because Poke is smart).
1101: PLUME: No one was badly injured from the escape pod’s impact. We’re incredibly fortunate.
1102: THATCH: This is good news, at least. Have we heard from Escape Pod 2 or Escape Pod 3?
1103: FILIX: No, I... I’m unable to make contact. My equipment can hear the other two escape pods’ distress signals, however. If it’s any comfort, both pods must be structurally intact.
1104: FILIX: I’ll continue calling for them.
1105: THATCH: My gratitude. If we can —
1106: PLUME: Thatch, the moon is approaching again!
1107: THATCH: Everyone brace yourselves, swiftly! The volcanic moon has returned!
1108: THATCH: Be cautious of falling ash and debris!
1109: PLUME: ...I believe the moon has passed.
1110: FILIX: This planet doesn’t appear eager to have guests. We are certainly unwelcome on its surface.
1111: THATCH: We need to find shelter, and quickly. The volcanic moon won’t be gone for long.
1112: PLUME: I observed several promising sites below the surface, but we’ll need to construct a way for everyone to climb safely down this cliff. Perhaps we could build platforms?
1113: CONOY: What have we learned thus far in our search for the Eye of the universe?
1114: PLUME: Those of us on the Vessel originally followed the Eye’s signal to this star system, but we were unable to warp to the Eye itself.
1115: PRIVET: The locator we built on the Attlerock and the new, more sensitive locator we built here were both unable to detect any trace of the Eye’s signal.
1116: AVENS: Hypothesis: The Eye has stopped emitting its signal.
1117: CASSAVA: Suppose the Eye doesn’t wish to be found.
1118: PLUME: Cassava, how can you suggest that? The Eye’s signal called out to summon us to this star system!
1119: CASSAVA: I’m aware; I grew up hearing the Eye’s story. Yet we’re no closer to finding it than you were when you first arrived here.
1120: MALLOW: Based on our knowledge of the Quantum Moon, we believe the Eye is in orbit around this star system’s sun. This would mean the Eye is located within a finite (albeit enormous) range.
1121: CONOY: How should our methods change as we continue our search for the Eye of the universe?
1122: PRIVET: As we couldn’t find the Eye’s signal using two different devices built for this exact purpose, we should discontinue this search method.
1123: MALLOW: We know what the Eye looks like thanks to the Quantum Moon, so what if we try to find the Eye visually, instead? Let’s send out a probe!
1124: CASSAVA: Mallow’s idea is clever, but we have no idea where the Eye is in relation to here. The probability of launching a probe in the correct direction would be absurdly small.
1125: CONOY: I believe I have a solution for that problem! Have you spoken with Ramie and Pye about the technology they’re developing?
1126: AVENS: We’d need to build a probe-launching mechanism to cover those long distances quickly. A cannon in orbit around a celestial body would circumvent the need to escape gravity’s pull.
1127: CASSAVA: Giant’s Deep would be a good choice. It’s furthest from the sun, so it would provide the best angles for launch. And it’s moonless (except when the Quantum Moon is visiting).
1128: AVENS: Yes, let’s build the cannon in orbit around Giant’s Deep!
1129: PLUME: The pain of your absence is sharp and haunting, and I would give anything not to know it; anything but never knowing you at all (which would be worse).
1130: PLUME: I can only hope that you are safe, Keek, wherever you are.
1131: KOUSA: We can hear the other escape pods’ distress signals, which gives me hope. Foli, are you still here? I am unsure how to survive in this place without you.
1132: KOUSA: (I am unsure how to be me without you.)
1133: PLUME: My brother wasn’t in Escape Pod 1 with us. Was he in Pod 2, or Pod 3? Was he able to board an escape pod at all?
1134: PLUME: We sacrificed too much arriving here. I cannot (I will not) allow our clan’s greatest loss to be in vain.
1135: THATCH: Is the hardest part of this tragedy not knowing who we may have lost? Or will the hardest part come later, when we learn? (Be well, Aunt Melorae...)
1136: PLUME: Given concerns about our settlement’s stability, where should we construct a new, less temporary shelter?
1137: THATCH: We need to stay close to the escape pod so Filix can monitor incoming messages. We can’t be rescued if we aren’t present to respond.
1138: FILIX: I don’t believe anyone is coming to save us, Thatch. Now we must save ourselves.
1139: PLUME: I agree. We’re here because the Eye’s signal called to us and we followed. If we’re to find it, we need to not merely survive, but thrive.
1140: PLUME: I believe we should migrate to the northern glacier.
1141: FILIX: What if we use gravity crystals to craft a stable path?
1142: THATCH: Building beneath the crust again would shelter us from the volcanic moon’s eruptions.
1143: THATCH: This is a wise point, Plume, and eloquently made. If moving to the northern glacier will keep us safer, then that is what we should do.
1144: FILIX: Has anyone observed the phantom moon that sometimes greets us in the night sky? Your thoughts interest me.
1145: THATCH: I compliment your eyes! How do you imagine it disappears? Hypothesis: Could it be a shift in the light spectrum?
1146: PLUME: Suppose this moon is too shy to show us its face.
1147: PLUME: I’m interested in your playful moon. Is it much like its violent friend (Hollow’s Lantern)?
1148: THATCH: Imagine if there were two volcanic moons.
1149: PLUME: Then I imagine there’d be none of us left!
1150: FILIX: Hypothesis: There can exist too much lava.
1151: THATCH: I’d strongly prefer we test the null hypothesis.
1152: FILIX: This moon isn’t volcanic (to my unaided eyes). Sometimes it leaves its friend Hollow’s Lantern for nights at a time.
1153: PLUME: The nights the moon circles this planet appear random. It seems to travel as it likes.
1154: If the Eye called to us, why won’t it reveal itself? Why is it so difficult to locate it?
1156: Did the signal stop? Does the Eye no longer desire to be found?
1157: Perhaps this isn’t the Eye’s choice. The Eye may not be able to communicate with us more than it already has.
1158: Did the Eye deliberately call out to us by sending the signal, or did we hear the signal by coincidence?
1159: We could be seeing meaning where there is none. Suppose the signal was produced incidentally.
1160: Does that mean the Eye is any less important, though?
1161: Perhaps the Eye wanted to be found (could it be sentient?). Maybe it chose us.
1162: Does the Eye desire something from us? Could it need us in some way?
1163: Maybe it doesn’t have to be us.
1164: Is the Eye natural, or artificial?
1166: The Eye is older than the universe itself. How could something exist before its creator?
1167: It could be naturally occurring, though this doesn't answer how the Eye could be as old as it is.
1168: Be welcomed in this place. This shrine is a space to reflect on what brought us to this star system: the signal from the Eye.
1169: We observed the Eye’s signal in our travels, and followed it here to find its source.
1170: What we know is this: The source of the signal (which we have chosen to call the Eye of the universe) is older than this universe itself. The rest, we have yet to learn.
1171: Enter, and open your mind to its possibilities.
1172: SOLANUM: I don’t know why everyone says the Eye is important.
1173: SOLANUM: They say it brought us to this solar system, but is that good? Dad told me lots of Nomai died when our clan came here.
1174: SOLANUM: What if the Eye wanted that to happen?
1175: SOLANUM: What if the Eye isn’t something good?
1180: ANNONA: We need status reports for all systems, but initial things first: Is everyone unharmed?
1181: RHUS: Our escape pod’s passengers are afraid, but physically well, Annona; everyone survived the crash.
1182: ANNONA: This is a relief, at least. You have my gratitude. Bur, were you able to find the other escape pods’ distress signals?
1183: BUR: I can hear both signals somewhere in this star system, but I don’t believe either escape pod crashed on the same planet as us.
1184: BEGIN FLIGHTLOG: Escape Pod 2. Vessel has been mortally injured. Emergency sequence activated. Awaiting departure from Vessel.
1185: Launching Escape Pod 3... Now launching Escape Pod 2.
1186:
Scanning external environment... Scan complete. External temperature is prohibitively high. 
Verdict: INHOSPITABLE. Do not seek shelter on planet surface.
1187: MELORAE: This is amazing (look inside the cave)! How did this come to rest here? We haven’t encountered others in these caves; I think this is a rare find.
1188: MELORAE: From what we can see, Coleus and I believe the specimen must be very old indeed. Imagine what we might learn if we could examine it!
1189: COLEUS: An update: We need to find a way inside quickly, Melorae, because when I returned here to search for an entrance to the cave, there were children playing on the specimen!
1190: COLEUS: We both agree it’s unlikely this dry planet is this horror’s place of origin (especially considering what we observed during the Vessel’s evacuation).
1191: MELORAE: Clearly this hole is too small for it to have fit through. Hypothesis: There is another entrance to this cave. If there is, Coleus and I will find it! We can’t leave valuable information undiscovered!
1192: MELORAE: We have found an enormous cavern at the end of this passage that appears promising! I believe we could construct long-term shelter there.
1193: ANNONA: The cavern Melorae found is a wise choice for shelter. Could one of you mark directions for the others to follow?
1194: COLEUS: This is the start of the path to the shelter site. I've left directions to guide you there.
1195: MELORAE: Of note: We must hurry, as the pathway there is filling with sand. Do not allow yourself to be buried by sand, and make sure no one is lost!
1197: COLEUS: An update: Melorae, while I was here making sketches of the anglerfish, I observed the children I saw earlier playing here again. They’ve added a rule to their game that incorporates our research (it’s wonderful)!
1198: MELORAE: I’m entirely delighted! It’s never too early to appreciate biology!
1199: COLEUS: This anglerfish’s digestive tract suggests death by starvation.
1200: MELORAE: Visually, the specimen appears to be of the same species as the anglerfish in Dark Bramble. We don’t believe it originated from this planet.
1201: MELORAE: The long growth protruding from its head is bioluminescent. Perhaps it used this growth to attract prey (a lure?).
1202: LAEVI: Whoever was it when we ended last time is the anglerfish.
1203: LAEVI: Rule change! The anglerfish now has to wear a blindfold. (And do not peek!)
1204: LAEVI: The rest of us (the littlefish) line up against one wall. When the anglerfish says go, the littlefish sneak across to the other side.
1205: LAEVI: If the anglerfish catches you, you’re eaten.
1206: LAEVI: Last littlefish to be caught is the new anglerfish! (The old anglerfish gives the new anglerfish the blindfold and becomes a littlefish.)
1207: LAMI: Why are we changing it? It’s too hard if you can’t see anything!
1208: LAEVI: Aunt Pye says real anglerfish are blind, so you have to wear a blindfold! The rule stands!
1209: ILEX: Rule update: It’s okay if younger kids don’t wear the blindfold when they’re it. (The rest of us will still wear it for scientific accuracy and to make the game more even.)
1210: MELORAE: This planet sometimes (and only sometimes) has a moon! This is also of note: It disappears if no one is watching it! Isn’t that a fascinating orbital characteristic?
1211: BUR: I found your note, Melorae; kindly count me among this moon’s admirers! What is happening when it disappears (I doubt it ceases to exist)? Does it move to another location?
1212: ANNONA: I believe so. Not only does the moon appear around Brittle Hollow, I can confirm it sometimes orbits Timber Hearth, as well.

1214: BUR: I agree! Our first step would be determining a method to track this phantom moon so that we can always know where it is.
1215: ANNONA: Given its reluctance to move while consciously observed, it might be a form of macroscopic quantum mechanics.

1217: COLEUS: Curious, but also alarming: This new cave appears to lack an entrance or exit. Also, the rock that brought me here disappeared while I wasn’t watching.
1218: COLEUS: The wandering rock has returned! Never before have I been so delighted to see a sedimentary specimen.
1219: COLEUS: I wonder if I myself became quantum briefly when the rock carried me here! This seems the clearest explanation. Hypothesis: If the rock can bring me here, it can also carry me out.
1220: COLEUS: My hypothesis was correct! I can travel on this rock, as long as I’m not observing my surroundings (meaning I must be in complete darkness). I’m going to bring my mentor here to see this.
1221: COLEUS: Melorae is here now, too. We theorize when a conscious being is in contact with a quantum object and ceases to act as an observer (explaining the need for darkness), the being can become entangled with that quantum object, and they move together.
1222: MELORAE: Friends, Coleus has discovered a new quantum rule! (He has also promised me he’ll never vanish again, even if he does learn something useful from it!)
1223: Melorae: Coleus is missing! He vanished from the Lakebed Cave (the one at the bottom of the dry lakebed at the north pole) several days ago, and we’re unable to find any trace of him. I don’t know how much air he had when he disappeared. I beg any friend reading this, help us recover Coleus!
1224: MELORAE: Friends, if you find any sign of Coleus, I implore you to tell me! He vanished without a trace during our research trip, and has been missing ever since.

1227: ANNONA: Where was young Coleus lost, Melorae?
1228: MELORAE: He disappeared in the cave at the bottom of the dry lakebed at the north pole. It happened in an instant, and without warning.
1229: MELORAE: I turned away from Coleus to examine a sample, and when I turned back, he simply wasn’t there anymore. He had a limited supply of air, Annona! I’m afraid for him!
1230: ANNONA: Hypothesis: We will learn more by examining the northern Lakebed Cave where Coleus disappeared. Search quickly, everyone; we have no time to squander!

1235: SECCA: To be so close to the location of the Vessel and still so far is... difficult. Worse, the Vessel’s beacon is dying; soon, we will be unable to hear it.
1236: SECCA: There is nothing we can do now but try to perhaps find a way inside, or at least attempt to comprehend why this happened.
1237: SECCA: My dearest hope is that the other escape pods were able to reach relative safety.

1297: YARROW: What happened? Did the Sun Station not fire?

1300: PYE: I don’t know what comes next, my friends. I suppose we must start over, but I’m unsure how to start over.

1704: This anglerfish specimen was found attached to the landing gear of one of our ships that flew close to Dark Bramble. It appears well-suited to living in dark places with minimal atmosphere.
1705: Of all the lifeforms who will perish in the oncoming death of the universe, we will miss the anglerfish the least.
1706: Outer Wilds Ventures, Timber Hearth’s first and only space program, was founded to explore the farthest reaches of our solar system.
1707: Feldspar was the first Hearthian to be intentionally launched into space. They completed the first orbit around Timber Hearth and later made the first of what would be many landings on our moon, the Attlerock.
1708: Outer Wilds Ventures was founded by Feldspar, Gossan, Slate, and Hornfels to explore a solar system at the end of the universe.

1739: This remarkably intact statue was carved by the Nomai, an ancient species who dwelled in our solar system thousands of years ago.
1740: The statue provides us with our most detailed look yet at the Nomai, who appear to have been covered with a layer of fur. Note the decorative jewelry that has been carved as part of the antlers.
1741: Although their artifacts and structures have been found on almost every planet in this solar system, we still have no idea where this species came from or what happened to them.
1742: This pilot seat, used by pioneering astronaut Feldspar, is all that remains of our inaugural flight into space.
1743: Although it’s been argued such a distinction requires a breathtakingly liberal definition of flight, that day will nevertheless always be remembered as a landmark achievement in Hearthian history.
1744: Aside from the dwellings and structures they built, the Nomai also made art. This decorated pottery was discovered on Brittle Hollow.
1745: Some ancient Nomai art depicts strange animals, foreign celestial objects, and other subjects that can’t be found in our solar system, which makes us wonder whether the Nomai originated elsewhere in the universe or simply had vibrant imaginations.
1746: Were the Nomai born in our solar system? Or were they born among other stars and planets - and if they were, how and why did they come here?
1747: These are just some of the questions we hope to answer through further xenoarchaeological expeditions.
1748: The Nomai technology brought back from space by our astronauts has been a great boon to Outer Wilds Ventures, allowing us to modify expedition gear in exciting and useful ways.
1749: For example, the Little Scout now boasts a warp retrieval capability that allows astronauts to recall their scouts almost instantly. This has dramatically reduced the number of scouts lost to the depths of space.
1750: The Nomai never got to see it for themselves, but thanks to their efforts and technology, a Hearthian was able to reach the Eye of the universe.
1751: The strange rock moving around in this grotto appears to react to conscious observation.
1752: The level-headed among us realize there must be some sort of optical illusion at play, but Gabbro claims the rock "exists in all possible states until it is observed" (whatever that means).
1753: Whatever is actually happening, both sides of this debate agree the effect is extremely creepy.
