1824: This piece of Nomai writing was essential to deciphering their unique language.
1825: Although this text is linear, Nomai text often branches off from a central point. Interestingly, each branch tends to be written by a different author.
1826: What you see here are parts of the Nomai skeleton. We can tell from their skulls that they possessed antlers and, quite unusually, only three eyes.
1827: The Nomai body was most likely adapted for living exclusively on land. The differences in the Nomai’s anatomy, such as their shockingly fragile bone structure, show us that Hearthians couldn’t have descended from Nomaian ancestors.
1828: It’s not clear where the Nomai originated from, or why they disappeared. We hope to find more clues to this puzzle as we explore our solar system.
1829: The Nomai who came to our solar system were following a signal from the Eye of the universe.
1830: They perished when the Interloper arrived, bringing with it the deadly substance we called ghost matter that flooded the entire solar system almost instantly and without warning.
1831: We never figured out how they died.
1832: Stars like our sun generate light and heat by fusing hydrogen into helium.
1833: As it grows older, the star runs out of hydrogen and starts to contract.
1834: As the star’s core contracts, it gets hotter, causing the outer layers to expand. The star has become a red giant.
1835: When the core is hot enough, it starts to fuse helium into carbon.
1836: If a star is massive enough, it will continue to fuse carbon into even heavier elements like iron.
1837: Ultimately, the star will collapse under its own gravity and then explode in a violent event called a supernova.
1838: Based on Chert's observations, this will one day be the fate of our own sun.
1839: At the end of its lifespan, our sun collapsed under its own gravity and then exploded in a violent supernova.
1840: Watch closely... these balls move on their own!
1841: The ground is perfectly level, so what do you think causes this spooky motion?
1842: The answer is the moon! As it orbits our planet, the Attlerock’s gravity pulls on objects from different directions. In fact, it’s pulling on you right now!
1843: ROOT: I was hoping to deliver new ore data to Poke in her Black Hole Forge, but the warp tower on the Twilight Twin sent me to the wrong part of Brittle Hollow.
1844: ROOT: Could someone kindly remind me if there’s a way to warp directly to the forge or if I imagined this?
1845: CLARY: There is! The Brittle Hollow warp tower that stands on the Twilight Twin will take you to two different places, including the forge. Just make sure you start at the correct place within the tower.
1846: ROOT: Of personal note: Remember to give Clary my gratitude when next I visit the Black Hole Forge.
1848: POKE: Clary and Root, kindly tune the alignments on each black hole core as I finish them. The schematic on the floor shows which warp tower aligns with which astral body.
1849: CLARY: To speed future deliveries to Ash Twin, I’ve tuned the first black hole core to activate when its warp tower aligns with Brittle Hollow.
1850: CLARY: And before anyone comments, yes, I am aware this reduces the distance between Yarrow and me.
1851: ROOT: The schematic shows the six towers on Ash Twin are being tuned to only five alignments. Is that a mistake?
1852: POKE: No, that’s correct. For these alignments we've decided to treat the Hourglass Twins as a single astral body.
1853: POKE: Have you seen Phlox’s tower designs in the High Energy Lab on Ember Twin? They clarify each tower’s warp destination.
1854: POKE: If it helps, you can imagine the Hourglass Twins as aligning with themselves.
1855: THATCH: This knowledge is too dear to lose: Here is everything we can recall about the signal we encountered while aboard the Vessel.
1856: FILIX: The signal looked like an eye: round, with a circle at the center much like a pupil. (Suppose the signal was looking for something.)
1857: FILIX: The signal was older than the universe itself! This is the most significant detail.
1858: PLUME: No Nomai clan has ever encountered anything like it! How can anything in this universe be older than the universe itself?
1859: THATCH: Imagine what rare and profound knowledge it might offer. We must find this Eye of the universe.
1876: The shuttle is currently resting at the comet.
1877: Who’s been computing shuttle trajectories to the Sun Station? Don’t worry; the station is in such a low stellar orbit, we’ve constructed a different, safer way to travel there from Ash Twin.
1878: IDAEA: That would be Pye. I told her we wouldn’t be traveling there by shuttle, and that the Sun Station doesn’t even have a landing pad, but she said she knew.
1879: PYE: It’s a purely theoretical exercise on my part, Yarrow. Who doesn’t love computing a good low stellar orbit shuttle trajectory!
1880: IDAEA: Pye, I look forward to working with you, but I’m also relieved it will be easy to return to Ash Twin regularly.
1881: MELORAE: This rock is very familiar! Did you travel here, my sedimentary friend? Because your unique color and texture appears identical to a rock I met earlier.
1882: MELORAE: Wasn’t this same rock fragment in the cave we found at the bottom of the dry lakebed (at the north pole)?
1883: COLEUS: An update: Melorae and I went back to the Lakebed Cave and observed this rock again. Sometimes it’s there, and sometimes it isn’t.
1884: MELORAE: That means this rock wanders like the Quantum Moon does. How curious!
1885: COLEUS: We plan to reexamine the northern Lakebed Cave. (Maybe our friendly rock will meet us down there!)
1896: We offer our congratulations! You’ve learned the rule of quantum imaging. Take this knowledge with you on the remainder of your quantum pilgrimage.
1897: Remember, the other quantum shards have other lessons to teach.
1898: Our curiosity goes with you on your journey. You walk in the footsteps of those who came before you, and your path guides those who will follow later.
1899: PHLOX: Yarrow, would you kindly step back so Daz is closest to the statue? When pairing, the statue will choose whoever is in closest proximity.
1900: PHLOX: ...See how its eyes have opened? That tells us the statue has paired with Daz. Now, no matter where he is in this star system, Daz’s statue will record his memories and send them to the Ash Twin Project.
1901: YARROW: This is extraordinary sculpting work, Phlox!
1902: DAZ: He has outdone himself again, hasn’t he? And now that we have our first successful pairing, we can test my memory storage prototype.
1903: DAZ: Each statue will send a single Nomai’s memories to his or her own storage unit within Ash Twin.
1904: PHLOX: Each storage unit will be equipped with a mask, the statue’s counterpart, which will be able to send those stored memories back to the corresponding Nomai.
1906: Cannon aligned with randomly selected probe trajectory. Gravity field activated.
1911: SOLANUM: There is fundamental uncertainty throughout the universe. Normally, this uncertainty is only observable on a very small scale. As one approaches the Eye, however, that uncertainty grows enormously.
1912: SOLANUM: The Quantum Moon probably exhibits macroscopic quantum behavior because of its proximity to the Eye. Shards that broke off from the Quantum Moon have a similar effect, as I imagine you’ve seen elsewhere in this star system.
1913: SOLANUM: Conscious observation forces a quantum object to collapse to a single possibility. But what would happen if a conscious observer somehow entered the Eye itself?
1914: SOLANUM: Over time, this has become my clan’s greatest question.
1915: SOLANUM: I imagine your purpose here is the same as mine: to learn about and to find the Eye of the universe.
1916: SOLANUM: I’m unsure how you arrived here, however. Perhaps you came from another star system, as my clan originally did?
1917: SOLANUM: Have you encountered a quantum shard on another planet? The shards look the same as the Quantum Moon’s surface does now, while at the Eye.
1918: SOLANUM: From this, we can reasonably infer the Quantum Moon’s natural state is as we see it now, and that the Eye is its primary location.
1919: SOLANUM: Given the Quantum Moon is the Eye’s moon, it’s likely that any characteristics the moon exhibits are also exhibited by the Eye itself. The Quantum Moon and its shards, for instance, are quantum; thus, the Eye is likely also quantum.
1920: SOLANUM: In fact, this moon is probably quantum because its proximity to the Eye made it quantum, the same way the areas surrounding quantum shards that landed on other planets eventually became quantum, too.
1921: SOLANUM: I am on my first pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon. All Nomai in my clan make this journey when we come of age.
1922: SOLANUM: Even though the Eye cannot be reached from here, the Quantum Moon remains special to us, as it carries us nearer to the Eye than any other place we know.
1923: SOLANUM: I’ve journeyed here to be close to the Eye. While the Eye is obscured from our sight, we can see the Quantum Moon’s reflection of the Eye in the sky above us.
1924: SOLANUM: Suppose you could reach the Eye of the universe: Would you try to enter it?
1925: SOLANUM: What do you imagine the effects of a conscious observer might be?
1926: SOLANUM: I imagine you’ve noticed the Quantum Moon changes in appearance depending on which location it is currently orbiting (for instance, the moon looks quite different when orbiting Giant's Deep than it does when orbiting the Hourglass Twins).
1927: SOLANUM: Because the Quantum Moon clearly changes in its different forms, the Eye (being this moon’s primary location) must be similarly malleable.
1928: SOLANUM: From this, we can hypothesize that the Eye represents extreme changeability.
1929: SOLANUM: That said, despite its malleable nature, the Quantum Moon becomes locked to one specific version of itself when it is consciously observed.
1930: SOLANUM: But what would happen if a conscious observer were to enter the Eye?
1931: SOLANUM: Many in my clan have believed the Eye called to us for a particular purpose.
1932: SOLANUM: When I was a child, I used to believe the Eye was malevolent, to have lured my clan to this star system only to then vanish from them so completely.
1933: SOLANUM: But I don’t fear the Eye, anymore. In fact, it became my fondest hope to see the Eye itself, someday, but I fear this may be beyond my reach.
1934: SOLANUM: You may think I’m strange, but I have a hypothesis that I may not be entirely alive. Perhaps my journey has reached its end.
1935: SOLANUM: These are the two tenets of Nomai philosophy; to seek out and to understand is our way of living.
1936: SOLANUM: We are orbiting the Eye of the universe now, although we cannot see it (only the Quantum Moon’s reflection of it). The Eye is older than the universe itself, and my clan believes it dwells in an extremely distant orbit around this star system.
1937: SOLANUM: I’ve never met one of your kind before. It’s an honor to speak with you! I particularly admire your four eyes.
1938: SOLANUM: There are many questions I would ask, if I could comprehend your language. You have my gratitude for understanding mine.
1939: SOLANUM: This is the Quantum Moon, where we both are standing.
1940: SOLANUM: Despite also orbiting other celestial bodies, the Quantum Moon is the Eye of the universe’s moon.
1941: SOLANUM: I am Solanum, a Nomai. My clan arrived in this star system before my birth, and we now call it home.
1942: SOLANUM: Is this your first time on the Quantum Moon? It’s my first time here.
1943: SOLANUM: If you’ve come here looking for answers, I hope you find them.
1944: SOLANUM: Like many of my clan before me, I journeyed here to see the Quantum Moon’s reflection of the Eye. This is the closest any of us have come to seeing the Eye itself.
1945: SOLANUM: We do not have much connection, you and I.
1946: SOLANUM: Still, this encounter feels special. I hope you won’t mind if I think of you as a friend.
1947: RAMIE: I’ve installed the masks inside the Ash Twin Project, Phlox. They look beautiful (although I do feel as though I’m being observed!).
1948: RAMIE: It’s comforting to know the statues will not pair until the project succeeds. Otherwise, I imagine the experience would be hard to endure!
1949: PHLOX: Ideally, they’ll only need to activate once the project succeeds; as a safety measure, however, the statues will also activate in the event of equipment failure.
1950: RAMIE: They will? Why is that?
1951: PHLOX: If anything goes wrong with the Ash Twin Project, the statues (and their masks) will make us aware of the situation and enable us to fix it. Otherwise, it would be possible for us to remain permanently unaware of the problem.
1952: RAMIE: I hadn’t thought of that! What a profoundly horrific fate that would be.
1953: ROOT: Friends in the Timber Hearth Mines, the last type of ore you sent us survives the longest in direct heat.
1954: ROOT: Can you send us more of the same for additional testing? We’re attempting to improve its durability, and our forge has already burned through everything you sent!
1955: OENO: We’ll deliver more ore to Hollow’s Lantern immediately. You must be fired up about crafting the Ash Twin Project’s protective shell!
1956: ROOT: Yes, the idea of an encasement that’s supernova-proof, however briefly, has kindled my curiosity!
1957: ROOT: My gratitude! I imagine we’ll also have an updated estimate soon of how much ore is needed to seal off the Ash Twin Project.
1958: OENO: Will it be more than we initially thought?
1959: ROOT: It will be significantly more. The smallest crack or opening in the protective shell would destroy everything.
1963: 281,042 YEARS AGO: No user commands received for 10 minutes. All systems entering sleep.

MASKS RECEIVING DATA FROM: 
Probe Tracking Module 
Giant's Deep memory statue 
Timber Hearth memory statue
1968: YARROW: Some time has passed since I checked in with you, Pye. How are you and Idaea progressing with the Sun Station plans?
1969: PYE: Presently, my assessment is that our plan will either fail explosively or succeed explosively.
1970: IDAEA: Pye, you know I don’t find that funny.
1971: PYE: How curious; Ramie thinks I’m a gas. And I don’t recall requesting that you monitor this conversation, Idaea.
1972: IDAEA: I don’t see what state of matter you are has to do with this. And I don’t recall supporting the Sun Station’s construction, but here we are.
1973: YARROW: Hypothesis: Time spent away from the station would be beneficial to you both.
1974: PYE: I’m immensely interested in testing your hypothesis, Yarrow.
1975: IDAEA: That, at least, we can agree on.

1978: I have a question for you.

1981: What’s weird is I’ve actually seen a couple of supernovae today. Usually, I’d be fortunate to see just one. Keep an eye or four on the stars, and maybe you’ll spot one yourself!
1982: Tell me, what can I do for you?
1984: How do I know if I've spotted a supernova?
1985: What are you doing out here?
1987: How dangerous is that big column of falling sand?
1989: Right now I’m documenting stars. Hornfels noticed our star charts are out of date, so they asked me to update them.
1990: Please don’t tell the others I said this, but sometimes I think I’m the only traveler out here interested in doing any science at all.
1991: ...Er, maybe don’t tell Hornfels, either. I think they’re pretty deep in denial.
1992: To be honest, I haven’t left this lakebed. I don’t mean to brag, but I’m really quite good with the Little Scout, so I’ve been taking pictures of everything from right here in my campsite.
1993: Have you seen the old shipwreck site on Ember Twin’s southern hemisphere, the one shooting a bright beam of light into the sky? It’s not one of our own crashes, surprisingly enough - this one’s a Nomai ship.
1994: You’ll find Nomai ruins across the Twins, but, strangely, not a single settlement! Believe me, if there was one to see, I’d have seen it with my Little Scout.
1995: So where did they live? Not on the surface, clearly. Ember Twin is full of cave systems, though - maybe the answer lies underground?
1996: On a scale of one to dead, I’d give it a seven or eight. Awfully pretty, though.
1997: Right now sand is flowing from Ash Twin to Ember Twin, but did you know the process eventually reverses? We're not completely sure why the sand flows back and forth between the Twins, but it seems to be a natural phenomena.
1998: Oh, if you’d like to see something interesting, check out the other Twin once a little more of its sand drains off. I promise you won’t be disappointed.
1999: Supernovae look like extra bright stars to the naked eye, but if you zoom in with your signalscope you can tell that they're actually enormous explosions.
2000: Massive stars go supernova at the very end of their life spans, which is why it's so unusual to see two in a single day.
2001: I wonder if some of these stars are older than we realized?

2015: I hope that puts your mind at ease.
2016: Did you! I hope they were useful?
2017: The planet I mentioned may have been frozen solid, or just partially made of ice, like a much colder Giant’s Deep - it’s hard to say. It used to be the fifth planet in our solar system.

2019: That is, Dark Bramble quite literally appeared at the center of the fifth planet and began destroying it from the inside-out. Eventually, the planet shattered completely, and its shards were flung across space.
2020: Some of these shards collided with the celestial bodies in our solar system, such as the Attlerock, which I believe is how its biggest crater was formed.
2021: How fascinating! It might interest you to know the existence of an additional planet is entirely plausible, if you look at the physics of our solar system. It would just have to be incredibly far out there - farther than Hearthian ships would be able to travel.

2026: Is that what’s in orbit around the sun, then, do you think? This... Sun Station?

2028: I wonder how were they able to travel back and forth from the Sun Station and the Hourglass Twins, when the slightest slip up would have meant a fiery death.

2145: A little. I’m in touch with ground control – Hornfels and Gossan, mostly – and they radio up to chat now and then.

2355: And this image covers just a tiny patch of the whole sky, which means the universe contains at least a thousand times more galaxies than we previously imagined.
2356: I... I think I need to sit down.

2359: It’s almost as if the entire universe is expanding.
2360: But if that’s true, was everything closer together in the past? And how far back can we extrapolate? Did the universe have a beginning?

2426: The one and only Hearthian village, as well as the main source of explosions on this planet.
2427: The Nomai statue in the observatory opened its eyes and looked at me! I saw strange glowing lights and my own memories flashed before my eyes.
2428: Hal says the statue has never opened its eyes before (despite Hornfels' best efforts).
2430: I hear Gossan has the zero-g cave set up if I want a refresher before I launch.
2431: A cave at the very center of Timber Hearth used by Outer Wilds Ventures to train new astronauts.
2432: I successfully repaired another "satellite" for Gossan.
2435: Esker's signalscope log reports harmonica music coming from somewhere on Timber Hearth. They claim it sounds just like Feldspar's harmonica, but Feldspar disappeared in space ages ago.
2436: A seed from Dark Bramble crashed here and has already taken root. Tektite wants to use a scout launcher to get a look at what's inside.
2437: My signalscope picks up harmonica music when I aim it at the seed.
2438: I launched my Little Scout into the seed. Somehow the seed is much bigger on the inside.
2440: The Nomai were mining ore somewhere on Timber Hearth.
2441: The Nomai mined ore from this site to craft a protective shell designed to physically seal off the central chamber inside Ash Twin.
2442: Once the shell was finished, the Nomai checked to ensure there were no longer any physical entrances or cracks.
2443: The Nomai discovered a species of four-eyed, semi-aquatic lifeforms in the waterways near the mine.
2446: Chert detected a strange signal coming from the crater at Timber Hearth's south pole. It's very similar to the signal emitted by the Quantum Moon.
2447: The Nomai detected a quantum signal coming from somewhere on Timber Hearth.
2448: There is a strange rock shard in this grove that moves when I’m not watching. It emits a signal on the Quantum Fluctuations frequency.
2449: I found a poem written on one of the trees in the grove.
2451: A radio tower designed to receive photos taken by the deep space satellite. There are several photos of the entire solar system hanging on the walls. Hornfels noticed something strange in one of the photos, but concluded equipment malfunction was the only sensible explanation.
2453: Riebeck headed to Brittle Hollow to investigate something the Nomai were doing at the south pole.
2454: Riebeck landed their ship near the big dome at the south pole. The door leading inside was broken, so they decided to head north to the ruins on the equator in search of a way beneath the surface.
2455: Riebeck discovered an old Nomai path near their campsite on the equator. The path starts inside the ruined building with trees growing out of it.
2456: Riebeck reached the Crossroads and continued downward in search of oxygen.
2457: Riebeck has set up camp at the bottom of the Crossroads. Their excitement at being surrounded by so much Nomai history is matched only by their terror of the black hole.
2458: Riebeck is Timber Hearth's only archaeologist. They overcame their fear of space to explore Brittle Hollow's treasure trove of Nomai culture.
2460: A huge cylindrical structure that generates a strong upward gravity field.
2461: I recalled a Nomai shuttle from the Quantum Moon.
2463: This tower (located on Brittle Hollow's equator) held useful knowledge for Nomai embarking on their first pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon.
2464: A Nomai named Solanum was told to visit the Tower of Quantum Knowledge (on Brittle Hollow's equator) to learn one final rule before embarking on her pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon.
2465: The Nomai built a shrine on the Quantum Moon to aid in the pilgrimage to its sixth location. "Remember this final rule: To explore the sixth location, the shrine must be on the moon’s north pole."
2466: The pilgrimage to the Quantum Moon was a deeply significant journey for the Nomai.
2467: After the two groups of Nomai stranded on Ember Twin and Brittle Hollow were reunited, it became their united goal to find and visit the Quantum Moon.
2469: The Nomai noticed a strange rock shard that appeared to wander when no one was watching.
2470: A strange rock shard that wanders when no one is watching. The Nomai determined this shard is the reason objects in this grove behave in a quantum manner.
2471: The Nomai hypothesized that this shard is actually a piece of the Quantum Moon.
2472: This shard emits the same signal as the Quantum Moon.
2474: The north pole of Brittle Hollow is covered in snow and ice. There is a uniquely shaped Nomai ruin on the surface.
2475: The Nomai were able to warp here from the White Hole Station. This is where they first recreated warp technology.
2477: One of the three Nomai escape pods landed somewhere on Brittle Hollow.
2478: One of three Nomai escape pods that crashed in our solar system.
2479: All three escape pods were launched from something called the Vessel, which was badly damaged.
2482: The Nomai survivors who crashed on Brittle Hollow climbed down the cliff to a shelter site below the surface.
2483: The Nomai constructed a temporary settlement beneath their crashed escape pod.
2484: The Nomai worked together to recall an eye-shaped signal they encountered while aboard the Vessel.
2485: The signal was somehow older than the universe itself. The Nomai decided to call it the "Eye of the universe."
2486: The Nomai abandoned this settlement over growing concerns about its stability.
2495: The Nomai decided to migrate from the Old Settlement to the northern glacier. They used gravity crystals to craft a stable path beneath the surface.
2496: There's a huge Nomai city just to the north of Riebeck's campsite.
2497: A Nomai city suspended beneath Brittle Hollow's northern glacier. The city is divided vertically into four districts.
2498: I found a switch in the Meltwater District that raises and lowers the Black Hole Forge.
2499: The Nomai debated how to obtain the powerful, highly advanced warp core required for the Ash Twin Project.
2500: The Nomai traveled to this solar system in pursuit of a signal from something older than the universe itself. They named the source of this signal the "Eye of the universe."
2502: The Black Hole Forge is suspended below the Hanging City. I found a switch in the Meltwater District that raises and lowers the forge.
2503: The Black Hole Forge District is the highest district in the Hanging City.
2504: A Nomai named Poke planned to create a new advanced warp core in the Black Hole Forge.
2505: The Nomai crafted warp cores at the Black Hole Forge before delivering them to Ash Twin.
2506: A warp tower's alignment point is not its warp receiver. Rather, a warp tower always aligns with the center of its corresponding astral body.
2507: The warp receiver must be located on (or in close orbit around) the relevant astral body.
2508: The Hourglass Twins are so close together they function as a single astral body, with a shared alignment point in between them.
2509: All of the warp towers were being constructed on Ash Twin, while the six warp receivers were being constructed at different locations.
2510: A Nomai named Poke successfully forged an advanced warp core for the Ash Twin Project.
2512: A diagram depicting the alignment angle between a warp tower and its corresponding astral body.
2513: Warp tower alignment angles are not exact. They only need to be within five degrees of the astral body's center.

2868: The Nomai were disappointed by their failure to detect a signal from something called the Eye of the universe.
2870: Several large Nomai towers form a ring around Ash Twin's equator.
2871: The White Hole Station was used as a model for these towers, which were built for the Ash Twin Project.
2873: The central chamber inside Ash Twin was physically sealed off by an immensely thick protective shell.
2874: The Nomai planned to construct technology capable of producing a 22-minute negative time interval on Ash Twin.
2875: Every memory recorded by a Nomai statue is transmitted to a corresponding storage unit within Ash Twin.
2876: An advanced warp core was approved for installation in the central chamber of Ash Twin.
2877: A hollowed-out chamber inside Ash Twin. The energy cables from the surface are plugged into a protective casing at the center of the planet.
2878: There are eight monoliths with Nomai masks attached. Three of the masks are actively receiving data from the Probe Tracking Module, Giant's Deep, and Timber Hearth respectively.
2879: The Ash Twin Project was designed to use the energy from a supernova (triggered by the Sun Station) to send probe data from the Orbital Probe Cannon 22 minutes into the past.
2880: The Sun Station did not work. Although the Ash Twin Project was theoretically sound, the Nomai were unable to power it.
2881: There is an advanced warp core inside the protective casing at the center of the planet. Removing the core will disable the Ash Twin Project.
2883: Ore samples from the Nomai Mines on Timber Hearth were sent to this volcano for durability testing.
2884: The Nomai were trying to craft a (briefly) supernova-proof shell to encase the Ash Twin Project.
2885: Even the smallest crack or opening in the protective shell would destroy everything.
2887: There is a White Hole Station on the other side of Brittle Hollow's black hole.
2888: Several Nomai returned to the station to investigate an equipment reading that appeared to violate causality.
2889: The experiments at the High Energy Lab were based on extraordinary findings from the White Hole Station.
2890: The towers on Ash Twin were modeled after the White Hole Station.
2891: Every Nomai warp tower is tuned to a specific astral body.
2892: To use a tower, you must be standing on the warp platform during the tower's alignment with its corresponding astral body (the alignment happens when the astral body is directly overhead).
2893: The Nomai noticed something strange: Warped objects appeared to arrive at the receiver on Brittle Hollow slightly before they departed the White Hole Station.
2894: This negative time interval between an object arriving and departing was incredibly miniscule (roughly one hundred-thousandth of a second). The Nomai were skeptical if their equipment could even measure time to such a small degree.
